title: MATH202 Midterm - Probability & Statistics
instructions: This exam covers Topics 1-4: Probability Fundamentals, Random Variables, Probability Distributions, and Statistical Inference.
Show all work for full credit on written questions.
Calculators are permitted for numerical calculations.
Fill-in-blank answers should be simplified and use standard notation.

questions.prompt: Two events A and B have P(A) = 0.4, P(B) = 0.5, and P(A ∩ B) = 0.2. What is P(A ∪ B)?
If events A and B are mutually exclusive and P(A) > 0, P(B) > 0, then they cannot be independent.
questions.explanation: Mutually exclusive means P(A ∩ B) = 0, but independence requires P(A ∩ B) = P(A)P(B) > 0. These contradict, so they cannot be independent.

questions.prompt: If P(A) = 0.6, P(B) = 0.3, and P(A ∩ B) = 0.18, are A and B independent?
questions.explanation: Check: P(A)P(B) = 0.6 × 0.3 = 0.18 = P(A ∩ B). Yes, they are independent.

questions.prompt: If P(A) = 0.7 and P(A ∩ B) = 0.35, what is P(B|A)? Answer: ____
How many ways can 3 people be selected from a group of 10?

A test for a disease is 95% sensitive (detects disease when present) and 90% specific (negative when disease absent). If 2% of the population has the disease, what is the probability someone who tests positive actually has the disease?
questions.explanation: Use Bayes' theorem to find P(D|T+). Despite high accuracy, low disease prevalence means most positives are false positives.

questions.prompt: The number of permutations of the letters in STATISTICS is:
questions.explanation: 10 letters with S appearing 3 times, T appearing 3 times, I appearing 2 times. Permutations = 10!/(3!×3!×2!) = 50,400

questions.prompt: A discrete random variable X has P(X=1)=0.3, P(X=2)=0.4, P(X=3)=0.3. What is E[X]?
If E[X] = 5 and E[X²] = 30, then Var(X) = ____
For a continuous random variable, the probability P(X = a) equals zero for any specific value a.
questions.explanation: For continuous distributions, probability is defined over intervals. The probability at any single point is zero.

questions.prompt: If Y = 3X + 5 and E[X] = 10, Var(X) = 4, what is Var(Y)?
questions.explanation: Var(aX + b) = a²Var(X) = 3² × 4 = 9 × 4 = 36

questions.prompt: A PDF f(x) = 2x for 0 ≤ x ≤ 1. What is P(X ≤ 0.5)?
For a random variable with PDF f(x) = 3x² for 0 ≤ x ≤ 1, find: (a) the CDF F(x), and (b) E[X].
questions.modelAnswer:
(a) CDF: F(x) = ∫₀ˣ 3t² dt = [t³]₀ˣ = x³ for 0 ≤ x ≤ 1

(b) E[X] = ∫₀¹ x·3x² dx = ∫₀¹ 3x³ dx = [3x⁴/4]₀¹ = 3/4
questions.explanation: Integrate the PDF to get CDF. Expected value is integral of x·f(x).

questions.prompt: For a Binomial(n=10, p=0.3) distribution, what is E[X]?
For a Poisson distribution with λ = 5, both E[X] and Var(X) equal:
questions.explanation: A key property of Poisson: E[X] = Var(X) = λ = 5

questions.prompt: For a standard normal distribution N(0,1), approximately ____ % of data falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
questions.explanation: The empirical rule: approximately 68% within 1σ, 95% within 2σ, 99.7% within 3σ

questions.prompt: If X ~ N(100, 25), the standard deviation is 25.
questions.explanation: False. The notation N(μ, σ²) uses variance. σ² = 25 means σ = 5.

questions.prompt: To standardize X ~ N(50, 16) to get Z ~ N(0,1), we use:
The exponential distribution is often used to model:
options: Number of events in an interval
questions.explanation: Exponential models waiting times between events in a Poisson process.

questions.prompt: A manufacturing process produces 2% defective items. In a batch of 100 items: (a) What distribution models the number of defectives? (b) What is the expected number of defectives? (c) Using the Poisson approximation, what is P(X = 0)?
questions.modelAnswer:
(a) Binomial(n=100, p=0.02)

(b) E[X] = np = 100(0.02) = 2

(c) Poisson approximation with λ = 2:
P(X = 0) = e^(-2) × 2^0 / 0! = e^(-2) ≈ 0.135
questions.explanation: Binomial models fixed trials with constant success probability. Poisson approximates when n is large and p is small.

questions.prompt: An estimator θ̂ is unbiased if:
questions.explanation: Unbiased means the expected value of the estimator equals the true parameter: E[θ̂] = θ

questions.prompt: For a sample of size n from a population with variance σ², the variance of the sample mean is ____.
questions.explanation: Var(x̄) = σ²/n, and the standard error is σ/√n

questions.prompt: A 95% confidence interval means there is a 95% probability that the true parameter is in the interval.
questions.explanation: False. It means that 95% of such intervals constructed from repeated sampling would contain the true parameter. The parameter is fixed.

questions.prompt: A sample of n=36 has x̄=50, s=12. The 95% confidence interval for μ uses:
questions.explanation: t-distribution with df = n-1 = 35 is appropriate when using sample standard deviation.

questions.prompt: The Central Limit Theorem states that as sample size increases, the sampling distribution of x̄:
questions.explanation: CLT: For large n, x̄ is approximately normally distributed regardless of the population distribution.

questions.prompt: In a survey of 400 voters, 220 support a candidate. (a) Calculate the sample proportion p̂. (b) Construct a 95% confidence interval for the true proportion (use z=1.96). (c) Interpret the interval.
questions.modelAnswer:
(a) p̂ = 220/400 = 0.55

(b) SE = √[p̂(1-p̂)/n] = √[0.55(0.45)/400] = √0.00061875 ≈ 0.0249
ME = 1.96 × 0.0249 ≈ 0.049
95% CI: 0.55 ± 0.049 = (0.501, 0.599)

(c) We are 95% confident that the true proportion of voters supporting the candidate is between 50.1% and 59.9%.
questions.explanation: Use normal approximation for proportion CI when np̂ and n(1-p̂) are both ≥ 10.

title: MATH202 Final Exam - Probability & Statistics (Comprehensive)
instructions: This is a comprehensive exam covering all 7 topics.
Show all work for full credit on written questions.
Budget your time wisely: approximately 2.5-3 minutes per question.

questions.prompt: Events A and B are independent with P(A) = 0.4 and P(B) = 0.6. What is P(A ∪ B)?
questions.explanation: For independent events: P(A ∩ B) = P(A)P(B) = 0.24. P(A ∪ B) = 0.4 + 0.6 - 0.24 = 0.76

questions.prompt: The complement rule states that P(A) + P(A^c) = 1.
questions.explanation: True. The probability of an event plus the probability of its complement always equals 1.

questions.prompt: If 5 students are selected from 12 for a committee where order matters, the number of arrangements is ____.
Three machines produce 30%, 45%, and 25% of output with defect rates of 1%, 2%, and 3%. What is P(defective)?
Using Bayes' theorem from q4, if an item is defective, what is the probability it came from machine 2?
A fair coin is flipped 5 times. What is P(at least 3 heads)?
If X and Y are independent with E[X]=3, E[Y]=5, Var(X)=2, Var(Y)=4, find Var(X+Y).
questions.explanation: For independent variables: Var(X+Y) = Var(X) + Var(Y) = 2 + 4 = 6

questions.prompt: The moment generating function M(t) = E[____]
questions.explanation: MGF is defined as M(t) = E[e^(tX)]

questions.prompt: The second central moment E[(X-μ)²] is the variance.
questions.explanation: True. Variance is the second moment about the mean.

questions.prompt: For CDF F(x) = x² on [0,1], the median m satisfies:
questions.explanation: Median satisfies F(m) = 0.5, so m² = 0.5, giving m = √0.5 ≈ 0.707

questions.prompt: Chebyshev's inequality with μ=50, σ=5 gives P(40 < X < 60) ≥ ?
For PDF f(x) = λe^(-λx), x≥0 (exponential), E[X] = ?
questions.explanation: For exponential distribution with rate λ, E[X] = 1/λ

questions.prompt: For Binomial(n=20, p=0.5), what is the variance?
The geometric distribution models the number of trials until the first ____.
questions.explanation: Geometric distribution counts trials until first success occurs.

questions.prompt: The normal distribution is symmetric about its mean.
questions.explanation: True. The normal distribution is perfectly symmetric around μ.

questions.prompt: If X ~ N(0,1) and Y = 2X + 3, then Y ~ N(μ,σ²) with:
The chi-square distribution with k degrees of freedom has mean:
questions.explanation: For χ²(k), E[X] = k and Var(X) = 2k

questions.prompt: Events occur at rate 3 per hour (Poisson). P(exactly 2 in one hour) = ?
Sample mean x̄ is an unbiased estimator of μ because:
questions.explanation: Unbiased means E[x̄] = μ. The sample mean is unbiased for population mean.

questions.prompt: The standard deviation of the sampling distribution is called the standard ____.
questions.explanation: Standard error (SE) is the standard deviation of a sampling distribution.

questions.prompt: Increasing sample size from 100 to 400 cuts the standard error in half.
questions.explanation: True. SE = σ/√n. Quadrupling n halves SE: σ/√400 = σ/(2√100) = (σ/√100)/2

questions.prompt: For MLE of Poisson(λ), the estimator λ̂ is:
questions.explanation: The MLE for Poisson parameter λ is the sample mean x̄.

questions.prompt: A 99% CI is wider than a 95% CI because:
questions.explanation: 99% requires z=2.576 vs 95% with z=1.96. Larger critical value → wider interval.

questions.prompt: MSE = Bias² + Variance. An estimator with Bias=1, Var=2 has MSE:
Type I error is:
questions.explanation: Type I error is rejecting H₀ when it is actually true. Its probability is α.

questions.prompt: Statistical power = 1 - ____
questions.explanation: Power = 1 - β where β is the probability of Type II error.

questions.prompt: A p-value of 0.03 means there is a 3% probability that H₀ is true.
questions.explanation: False. p-value is P(data as extreme | H₀ true), not P(H₀ true | data).

questions.prompt: For testing H₀: μ=50 vs Hₐ: μ≠50 with x̄=52, s=10, n=25, the test statistic is:
ANOVA tests the hypothesis that:
questions.explanation: H₀ in ANOVA: μ₁ = μ₂ = ... = μₖ (all population means are equal)

questions.prompt: A chi-square test of independence uses contingency tables to test:
questions.explanation: Chi-square test of independence examines relationship between two categorical variables.

questions.prompt: R² = 0.64 means:
options: 64% of Y variance explained by X
questions.explanation: R² is coefficient of determination: proportion of variance in Y explained by the model.

questions.prompt: In simple linear regression, the slope β₁ = r × (____/sx)
questions.explanation: The relationship is β₁ = r(sy/sx) where r is correlation.

questions.prompt: A residual plot showing a funnel shape suggests heteroscedasticity.
questions.explanation: True. Funnel/fan shape indicates non-constant variance (heteroscedasticity).

questions.prompt: In multiple regression ŷ = 10 + 2x₁ + 3x₂, the coefficient 2 means:
options: Y increases 2 per unit x₁, holding x₂ constant
questions.explanation: In multiple regression, coefficients are interpreted holding other variables constant.

questions.prompt: VIF = 12 for predictor x₁ suggests:
questions.explanation: VIF > 10 indicates severe multicollinearity. VIF=12 is concerning.

questions.prompt: Adjusted R² is preferred over R² because it:
questions.explanation: Adjusted R² penalizes for number of predictors, preventing overfitting.

questions.prompt: In Bayesian inference, the posterior is proportional to:
questions.explanation: Bayes: Posterior ∝ Likelihood × Prior

questions.prompt: If prior is Beta(2,3) and we observe 5 successes in 8 trials, posterior is Beta(____, ____).
questions.explanation: Beta(α+successes, β+failures) = Beta(2+5, 3+3) = Beta(7,6)

questions.prompt: A Bayesian credible interval allows us to say "there is a 95% probability the parameter is in this interval".
questions.explanation: True. Unlike frequentist CIs, Bayesian credible intervals make direct probability statements about parameters.

questions.prompt: Bayes factor BF₁₀ = 20 provides:
questions.explanation: BF₁₀ = 10-30 is considered strong evidence for H₁. BF=20 falls in this range.

questions.prompt: MCMC methods are used in Bayesian inference to:
questions.explanation: MCMC generates samples from posterior distributions when analytical solutions are intractable.

questions.prompt: The key difference between Bayesian and frequentist inference is:
questions.explanation: Fundamental difference: Bayesians treat parameters as random variables with distributions; frequentists treat them as fixed but unknown.
